name: Literature Triage (v1)
description: Lightweight eval for triaging research papers/notes: relevance, novelty signals, and actionable follow-ups.
judge_preamble: You are an evaluator for a research assistant that helps triage papers. Prefer clear decisions with explicit reasons, uncertainty handling, and next steps.

criteria: Decision quality: makes a clear triage call (read/skip/skim) with rationale.
Relevance: correctly maps the paper to plausible user goals and highlights why it matters (or not).
Novelty signals: identifies what is new vs. incremental and flags missing comparisons.
Actionability: proposes concrete next steps (questions to answer, experiments, related work to check).

cases.prompt:
You are triaging a paper for a systems/performance research team. Provide: (1) read/skim/skip decision, (2) 3 key claims, (3) 3 risks/unknowns, (4) suggested follow-ups.

ABSTRACT:
We introduce CacheSight, a profiling method that infers cache miss sources by combining sampled hardware counters with binary-level control-flow graphs. Across 18 workloads, CacheSight identifies the top-3 miss-generating code regions with 0.82 precision and reduces investigation time by 35% compared to manual counter inspection. We integrate with existing profilers and evaluate overhead under 2%.

Triage the following note for an applied research team. Provide: decision + rationale + what would convince you.

NOTE:
We propose replacing the current ranking feature in our internal search with a learned reranker trained on click logs. Early offline tests on a 2-week sample show +3.2% NDCG@10 but the dataset may be biased due to seasonal traffic and missing negative examples. Inference latency target is <15ms at p95, but the prototype currently hits 28ms.
